author: David K. Li
title: FIFA bans Sepp Blatter for 90 days
text:
An internal watchdog panel slapped embattled FIFA president Sepp Blatter with a 90-day suspension Thursday, citing ethics violations.
Blatter, European soccer chief Michael Francois Platini and FIFA Secretary General Jerome Valcke were all handed three-month bans — which could be extended for another 45 days.
The corruption penalties could mark the end for scandal-plagued Blatter, who was up for re-election in February.
Platini was considered a favorite to win the next FIFA election to take Blatter’s spot.
“The grounds for these decisions are the investigations that are being carried out by the investigatory chamber of the ethics committee,” FIFA said.
Ex-FIFA VP Chung Mong-joon was banned for six years and fined more than $100,000.
“President Blatter was disappointed that the Ethics Committee did not follow the code of ethics and disciplinary code, both of which provide for an opportunity to be heard,” according to a statement by Blatter’s legal team.
Swiss prosecutors are investigating Blatter over a possible, improper $2 million payment made to Platini.
Blatter’s lawyer, Richard Cullen, said his client hasn’t been criminally charged so he shouldn’t be forced out of his job.
“The attorney general in Switzerland … opened an investigation but brought no charge against the president,” Cullen said in a statement. “In fact, the prosecutors will be obliged by law to dismiss the case if their investigation, barely two weeks old, does not establish sufficient evidence.
He added: “President Blatter looks forward to the opportunity to present evidence that will demonstrate that he did not engage in any misconduct, criminal or otherwise.”
With Blatter’s removal, the world’s top soccer job fell to Issa Hayatou, FIFA’s senior vice president.
The son of a sultan from northern Cameroon, Hayatou said he’ll only be a caretaker president won’t see the job permanently.
Hayatou has also been accused to ethical lapses in the past.
He pledged to “dedicate my best efforts to the organization” in his short upcoming time at FIFA’s helm.
“FIFA remains committed to the reform process, which is critical to reclaiming public trust,” Hayatou said. “We will always continue to cooperate fully with authorities and follow the internal investigation wherever it leads.”
